awd_abstract_narration:
Wrist-worn wearable devices provide rich sets of pulsatile physiological data under various modalities and circumstances. An unexploited capability is that the pulsatile physiological time series collected by wrist-worn wearable devices can be used for recovering internal brain dynamics. The goal of this project is to present wearable machine-interface (WMI) architectures related to mental stress and their potential applications for tracking fatigue and arousal states. Decoding brain states using wrist-worn wearables will transform how mental-stress-related diseases are diagnosed and treated. The research is integrated with education and outreach activities with an emphasis on increasing the participation of minorities in science and engineering. These activities include hosting hands-on STEM events for elementary school and high school students, hosting undergraduate research interns, and creating educational videos. 

This proposal presents two design classes of WMI architectures related to mental stress: (1) A decoder that recovers undesired stimuli-triggered brain pulses from wrist-worn wearables and a controller that delivers closed-loop intermittent stimulation to reverse the adverse effect of undesired stimuli; and, (2) a decoder that recovers undesired stimuli-triggered inhibition of pulsatile physiological profile from wrist-worn wearables and a controller that delivers closed-loop intermittent stimulation to generate the desired pulsatile physiological profile. The proposed methods will be validated by analyzing electro-dermal activity as well as concurrent cortisol and adrenocorticotropic hormone pulsatile data in the context of mental-stress-related arousal and fatigue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

CRII Outcomes: The outcomes of the CRII project were shared with the research community through multiple talks by Faghih and her group members, peer-reviewed journal and conference publications, publicly available GitHub code repositories and educational YouTube videos, and media attentions featuring this research.

Intellectual Merit: The focus of this CRII project was on a design class of wearable-machine interface architectures that (1) infers brain impulsive profiles from skin conductance or cortisol data, (2) estimates unobserved arousal or energy-related states, (3) simulates feedback control to maintain unobserved arousal or energy-related states within a desired range. This CRII award had a fundamental impact on the interface between engineering and neuroscience and created new opportunities for quantifying internal brain dynamics that are important for diagnosis and treatment of neuropsychiatric and hormonal disorders. The contributions included development of (1) system-theoretic physiological models, (2) biomedical system identification methods, (3) time and frequency domain optimization frameworks, (4) physiological Bayesian state-space estimation algorithms, (5) physiologically inspired control techniques. The toolsets developed have applications throughout engineering, neuroscience, and medical sciences.

Broader Impact: With different outreach activities, PI Faghih hopes she can encourage the next generation, particularly, girls and under-represented minorities to pursue a higher education in STEM fields. Faghih and her group were extensively involved in outreach activities. For example: (1) Faghih's lab hosted over 80 girls as a part of the "Chevron Girls Engineering the Future" event in 2019. The girls were 4-8th graders in Houston. (2) The Faghih served as panelist for H-Town Tech Camp Outreach to high school students at HP Houston in 2019. (3) Faghih served as a panelist for Montgomery College Engineering and Computer Science virtual career path event in 2021 and provided advice to community college students on transferring to 4-year universities.

Selected Awards and Recognitions: This CRII program has been very successful, and the research outcomes resulted in multiple awards and recognitions. Examples of PI recognitions include: (1) MIT Technology Review selected Faghih as one of the visionaries in its global list of Innovators Under 35 for the year 2020. (2) In 2020, Futuroprossimo, an Italian futurology magazine included her on a list of early career female researchers that have the highest potential for a Nobel Prize in the future. (3)  In June 2020, IEEE Women in Engineering Magazine highlighted Faghih as a "Woman to Watch." Examples of PhD student recognitions include: (1) Cullen Graduate Fellowship Travel to all three PhD students, (2) selection of one PhD student for the University of Houston (UH) Cullen College of Engineering Future Faculty Program, (3) honorable mention award at the UH Graduate Research Showcase for another PhD student. Examples of MS student awards include: (1) Second place Exchange International TX South award at the UH Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Graduate Research Conference, (2) National Science Foundation registration award for the IEEE Biomedical and Health Informatics Conference. Examples of undergraduate student awards include: (1) One undergraduate received an audience favorite award at the UH Undergraduate Research Day. (2) Three undergraduates received UH Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowships. (3) One senior design team came second in the UH's ECE capstone design competition.

Workforce Development: The CRII program created various training opportunities. Three PhD students and four MS students graduated from UH under the supervision of Faghih. Out of Faghih's PhD graduates, two joined Tech companies and one accepted a postdoctoral position at the Department of Neurological Surgery at the University of California, San Francisco, and is completing his postdoctoral training. Out of Faghih's MS students, two joined Tech companies and two are continuing their studies as Biomedical Engineering PhD students, one at UH and one at Faghih's lab at the New York University. The CRII program has resulted in the training undergraduate students through senior design projects (27 students), undergraduate research experiences (11 students), and business plan development (8 Entrepreneurship students). Seven senior design projects that involved the development of wearable devices for vital sign monitoring, cardiac activity monitoring, attentiveness monitoring, facial expression identification, emotion recognition, stress regulation, and activity recognition were mentored in Faghih's research group. During the course of this CRII project, at UH, Faghih developed and taught an advanced graduate-level course on state-space estimation, with physiological and neuroscience applications. Faghih formulated data science projects for teams of students as a part of the course. The problems formulated were research questions and the course projects have resulted in four peer-reviewed IEEE conference papers and two peer-reviewed journal publications. Faghih received superior ratings for her teaching, and in the 2019-2020 academic year, the UH's Cullen College of Engineering recognized the Faghih with an Engineering school-wide Teaching Excellence Award for outstanding teaching and service to students.  

The PI and her group members are grateful to the National Science Foundation for supporting this research program and thank Dr. Ralph Wachter for serving as the NSF Program Officer.
